## Why the questions matter 

<style>
table, th, td {
  border: 1px solid black;
  border-collapse: collapse;
}
</style>

<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<TR VALIGN=TOP>
    <th> </th>
    <th> Question</th>
    <th> Why do I need to know the answer to this?</th>

</tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>

<td height=67 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:50.0pt;width:24pt'>Q26</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=319 style='border-left:none;width:240pt'>How will the
  data in the analysis be processed before and during use?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-left:none;width:297pt'>Operations
  on the data inputs will have wide-ranging effects on processes and outputs. A
  clear understanding of how these processes affect the workflow is essential
  for understanding quality.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=33 style='height:25.0pt'>
  <td height=33 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:25.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q27</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Is the data appropriate given the methods selected?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>A comprehensive understanding of data inputs is a prerequisite
  to meeting user needs.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=133 style='height:100.0pt'>
  <td height=133 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:100.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q28</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>What are the strengths and limitations of the datayou
  use?<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>Not all data can be used to answer particular research questions.
  The formatting, the time scale, the granularity must all be assessed and
  found relevant to the research question. A comprehensive understanding of
  data inputs is a prerequisite to meeting user needs. Without understanding
  where data is strong and where it is weak, it is impossible to make
  meaningful improvements to the analysis and/or the inputs to manage the
  limitations.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>    </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=167 style='height:125.0pt'>
  <td height=167 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:125.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q29</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Is there a robust relationship between your team and data
  providers? Do data providers understand how and why you use their data?<br>
    Do you understand how data providers collect,
  process and quality assure the data you use?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>A good relationship with data suppliers helps to make sure that
  the data they supply meet your requirements. Lack of communication can mean
  you are not aware of quality risks or changes in collection or processing
  steps that may affect your results. You should be able to communicate with
  your suppliers as often as you need to to manage input quality. Data
  providers should also have a good understanding of how and why you are using
  their data. This can help them to improve data quality, value, and identify
  and address any gaps or issues that are relevant for your analysis.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=100 style='height:75.0pt'>
  <td height=100 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:75.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q30</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Is there a formal agreement to set out data content, when
  and how you will get the data? If not, do you think this would be
  helpful?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>A formal service level agreement with data providers makes sure that everybody
  understands what will be delivered, when and how. This is useful for setting
  out clearly the division of responsibilities between data providers and your
  team for getting and sharing the data. It might specify formats, delivery,
  timescale, legal framework, accompanying metadata and quality checks.<span
  style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=100 style='height:75.0pt'>
  <td height=100 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:75.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q31</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Do you know what quality checks are carried out on the data
  before you receive them?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>Data suppliers should be able to show that their data is sufficiently assured
   and meets your needs. Simply having a quality report is not enough. You should
  be able to demonstrate that the data meet your needs and that
  reported quality matches what you observe in practice.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q32</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>How will you work with your data provider when your data
  requirements change?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>Review your data requirements regularly to ensure
  they are still relevant and feasible. Changes to requirements should be
  communicated to data providers well in advance and agreed by all
  stakeholders. If there is a formal agreement, it may need to be revised as
  requirements change.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=117 style='height:87.5pt'>
  <td height=117 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:87.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q33</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>How do you know if your data provider makes a change to their
  systems or processes which could impact the data you receive or the
  analysis you produce?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>Data suppliers make changes to their definitions, methods and
  systems. This may not affect the quality of their data but can
  impact on how you process the data and what you can infer
  from it. Tailor communication with data suppliers so it sufficiently
 frequent, effective and ongoing to get timely information about changes they make.<span
  style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q34</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>How did you choose the methods for the analysis? How do you know
  the methods you use are appropriate?<span
  style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>You should be able to explain why you chose your methods. For each method,
  document the underlying assumptions, why the method is suitable for answering the analysis question,
  why it is applicable to the type and distribution of data you are using, and how these decisions were signed off.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=133 style='height:100.0pt'>
  <td height=133 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:100.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q35</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Have reasonable alternative methods been explored and
  rejected for good reasons?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>There is often more than one way to meet the objectives of analysis.
  When you have made choices about methods and approaches, explain how and why
  you considered and rejected other options. Unless there is evidence underpinning your choice, users cannot
  be sure that you have considered and rejected reasonable alternatives for good reasons.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q36</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>How do you know that your analysis is working correctly?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>You need to be sure that your analysis produces the outputs that
  you think it should and that the processes you run work as expected. If you
  cannot demonstrate that scripts and processes you have set up work
  correctly, you cannot confirm the quality of the results.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=183 style='height:137.5pt'>
  <td height=183 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:137.5pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q37</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Can you describe the assumptions of your analysis, when they
  were made and who made them and signed them off?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>You must understand the assumptions your analysis makes.
  Assumptions set out how the analysis simplifies the world and mitigates uncertainty.
  If assumptions are inadequately set out or absent, important characteristics of the analysis and its inputs will
  be opaque, greatly increasing risk. Without a comprehensive log of all
  assumptions made by the analysis, an audit trail back to sources signed off by
  assumption owners, a version control log reflecting when assumptions were last
  updated and evidence reflecting internal and external validation of
  assumptions, uncertainties may go unacknowledged and could drastically impact
  the outputs.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q38</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>How are assumptions validated and assured before you apply them?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>A clear understanding of how assumptions have been externall and
  internally validated and signed off gives us confidence that they are
  reasonable.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=233 style='height:175.0pt'>
  <td height=233 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:175.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q39</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>How do you measure and report uncertainty in your analysis?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>All analysis contain some degree of uncertainty that may come
  from a variety of sources. Reporting uncertainties is important to inform
  users of how precisely we can give our reported values or how much confidence
  users can have in the analysis. It could also help your team to determine
  where an analysis can be improved. There are many ways to quantify
  uncertainty in input data, assumptions, processes and outputs. There is no
  ‘one size fits all’ approach. For instance, the size and distribution of the
  uncertainties in analytical inputs can be understood by comparing different
  data sources, understanding the probability distribution, break-even
  analysis, using expert judgement or historical data to inform ranges.
  Uncertainty in model outputs can be assessed with Monte Carlo techniques,
  convolution, scenario analysis,<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
  </span>previous forecasts, expert judgement, etc.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q40</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Have you considered the implications of any unquantified
  uncertainties?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>A good understanding of the uncertainties in the analysis
  workflow is critical to ensure the model and its outputs are fit for purpose.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q41</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Can you explain the impact of your analysis on downstream
  processes? Are there any risks around these dependencies?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>Understanding how your analysis would be used by the primary and
  secondary users would help to ensure that the right quality and assurance
  levels are in place. It would help you to assess the risks around the use of
  analysis and if there are other stakeholders or users you need to
  consult.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>            </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q42</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Is all or part of the analysis reliant on a single person?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>Single points of failure carry significant business risk. If
  there is only one person who understands how to carry out all or part of the
  analysis then the process is extremely vulnerable.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=67 style='height:50.0pt'>
  <td height=67 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:50.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q43</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Is it clear why important decisions about the analysis were made, who made them and when?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>All analysis involves decisions. A comprehensive record of the
  decisions made in specifying and conducting the analysis ensures that we have
  a full audit trail of why decisions were made, who made them and signed them
  off.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q44</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>If changes need to be made to code or datasets, is it
  easy to track who made the changes and when and why they were
  made?<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>Good version control ensures that you have a full understanding
  of when, why and how changes were made to your analysis process. If it is
  hard to track changes, this makes it hard to retrace steps if there is a
  problem and means you do not fully understand the process</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=117 style='height:87.5pt'>
  <td height=117 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:87.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q45</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Would another analyst be able to reproduce your analysis output or
  continue the work without talking to you first?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>Your analysis must be well documented and repeatable so that
  somebody new can understand it, pick it up and produce the same output using
  the same inputs. Poor documentation means that other people will not
  understand why the process is configured as it is, how the process works, how
  to run the process safely and produce the same output- potentially leading to
  errors.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=117 style='height:87.5pt'>
  <td height=117 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:87.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q46</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Do you use internal peer review to check scripts and code,
  documentation, implementation of methods, processes and outputs?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>The team should independently review and validate the logical
  integrity of its analysis as well as the structure and functionality of the
  code against the research question the analysis asks. A record of validation
  and verification activities undertaken, outstanding activities and remedial
  actions is important to understand that the correct analysis has been
  performed for the purpose it is used for and the chosen approach minimises
  risk.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=67 style='height:50.0pt'>
  <td height=67 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:50.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q47</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Is your code and analysis ever peer reviewed by someone outside
  your team or organisation?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>External peer review is one of the best ways to ensure that the
  analysis and code are well made and fit for purpose. Without it, teams may
  reinforce their own biases and will be unable to notice there is anything
  wrong.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=100 style='height:75.0pt'>
  <td height=100 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:75.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q48</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>What is your assessment of the quality of your analytical
  outputs?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>Understanding and reporting on the quality of your analytical
  outputs is critical to ensure fitness for purpose, as well as trust and
  reliability. This ensures that analysis can appropriately inform
  decision-making. Your quality assessments are also key information to be
  shared with your users as well as being a requirement of the Code of Practice
  for Statistics.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=150 style='height:112.5pt'>
  <td height=150 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:112.5pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q49</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>How do you assure yourselves that analysis you do is
  correct?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>It is important to aasure the results fit with your expectations
  and you are able to explain why there are any discrepancies. It makes it
  easier to mitigate risk appropriately. There are various ways of assuring if
  the analysis is carried out correctly. For example, sensitivity analysis can
  help in understanding which inputs are having the greatest effect on the
  outputs, and which procesess within the model are the most critical.You can
  also compare figures from your analysis with any similar earlier analysis or
  test your data against historical series.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q50</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Do the outputs of your analysis align with similar findings from elsewhere? If not can you explain why?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>When you can, check that your outputs align with
  findings from alternate data sources, previous methods and comparable
  studies. This gives you confidence that the analysis is performing as
  expected. You should be able to explain any inconsistencies that you see.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=100 style='height:75.0pt'>
  <td height=100 class=xl6619059 width=31 style='height:75.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q51</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>If you find outliers or unusual trends in the data, what steps
  do you take to investigate them?</td>
  <td class=xl6619059 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>It is crucial to identify unusual trends in the data and
  understand why they are there. Not all outliers are
  the same. Some have a strong influence, some not at all. Some are valid and
  important data values and some might be errors. Investigate outliers 
  thoroughly and take reasonable steps to check their
  impact on your final output. If you choose to exclude unusual values you should explain why this is acceptable.</td>
  </tr>
</table>

 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>

<td height=50 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;width:24pt'>Q26</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-left:none;width:241pt'>How will the
  data used in the analysis be processed before and during use?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-left:none;width:276pt'>Q1
  Statistics should be based on the most appropriate data to meet intended
  uses. The impact of any data limitations for use should be assessed,
  minimised and explained.</td>

 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q27</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Is the data appropriate given the methods selected?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q1 Statistics should be based on the most appropriate data to
  meet intended uses. The impact of any data limitations for use should be
  assessed, minimised and explained.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=100 style='height:75.0pt'>
  <td height=100 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:75.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q28</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>What are the strengths and limitations of the data you
  use?<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q1 Statistics should be based on the most appropriate data to
  meet intended uses. The impact of any data limitations for use should be
  assessed, minimised and explained. Q1.5 Potential bias, uncertainty and
  possible distortive effects in the source data should be identified and the
  extent of any impact on the statistics should be clearly reported.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=117 style='height:87.5pt'>
  <td height=117 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:87.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q29</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Is there a robust relationship between your team and data
  providers? Do data providers understand how and why
  you use their data?<br>
    Do you understand how data providers collect,
  process and quality assure the data you use?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q1.2 Statistics producers should establish and maintain
  constructive relationships with those involved in the collection, recording,
  supply, linking and quality assurance of data, wherever possible.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=67 style='height:50.0pt'>
  <td height=67 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:50.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q30</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Is there a formal agreement to set out data content, when
  and how you will get the data? If not, do you think this would be
  helpful?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q1.3 A clear statement of data requirements should be shared
  with the organisations that provide that data, setting out decisions on
  timing, definitions and format of data supply, and explaining how and why the
  data will be used.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q31</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Do you know what quality checks are carried out on the data
  before you receive them?</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q1 Statistics should be based on the most appropriate data to
  meet intended uses. The impact of any data limitations for use should be
  assessed, minimised and explained.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=67 style='height:50.0pt'>
  <td height=67 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:50.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q32</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How will you work with your data provider when your data
  requirements change?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q1.2 Statistics producers should establish and maintain
  constructive relationships with those involved in the collection, recording,
  supply, linking and quality assurance of data, wherever possible.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=150 style='height:112.5pt'>
  <td height=150 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:112.5pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q33</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How do you know if your data provider makes a change to their
  systems or processes, which could impact the data you receive and/or the
  statistics you produce?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q1.2 Statistics producers should establish and maintain
  constructive relationships with those involved in the collection, recording,
  supply, linking and quality assurance of data, wherever possible. Q1.7 The
  impact of changes in the circumstances and context of a data <br>
    source on the statistics over time should be evaluated. Reasons for any
  lack of consistency and related implications for use should be <br>
    clearly explained to users.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q34</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How did you choose the methods for the analysis? How do you know
  the method you are using is appropriate?<span
  style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q2 Producers of statistics and data should use the best
  available methods and recognised standards, and be open about their
  decisions.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q35</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Are reasonable alternative methods have been explored and
  rejected for good reasons?</td>
  <td class=xl6719059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q2 Producers of statistics and data should use the best
  available methods and recognised standards, and be open about their
  decisions.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q36</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How do you know that your analysis or statistical process is
  working correctly?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q3 Producers of statistics and data should explain clearly how
  they assure themselves that statistics and data are accurate, reliable,
  coherent and timely.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=133 style='height:100.0pt'>
  <td height=133 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:100.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q37</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Can you describe the assumptions of your analysis, when they
  were made and who made them and signed them off?</td>
  <td class=xl6819059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Transparency (cross cutting theme) is needed about processes,
  methodology and content. Transparency means being clear and open, for
  example, about the choices being made – and not holding back or being opaque
  about decisions. Within Quality, producers should explain what judgements
  they have made about the data and methods, and their strengths and
  limitations. These explanations are as important as the numbers themselves.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=200 style='height:150.0pt'>
  <td height=200 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:150.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q38</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How the assumptions are validated and assured prior to use?</td>
  <td class=xl6819059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Transparency (cross-cutting theme) is needed about processes,
  methodology and content. Transparency means being clear and open, for
  example, about the choices being made – and not holding back or being opaque
  about decisions. Within Quality, producers should explain what judgements
  they have made about the data and methods, and their strengths and
  limitations. These explanations are as important as the numbers themselves.
  Q3.5 Systematic and periodic reviews on the strengths and limitations in the
  data and methods should be undertaken. Statistics producers should be open in
  addressing the issues identified and be transparent about their decisions on
  whether to act.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q39</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How do you measure and report uncertainty in your analysis?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q2.4 Relevant limitations arising from the methods and their
  application, including bias and uncertainty, should be identified and
  explained to users. An indication of their likely scale and the steps taken
  to reduce their impact on the statistics should be included in the
  explanation.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=117 style='height:87.5pt'>
  <td height=117 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:87.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q40</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Have you considered the implications of any unquantified
  uncertainties?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q2.4 Relevant limitations arising from the methods and their
  application, including bias and uncertainty, should be identified and
  explained to users. An indication of their likely scale and the steps taken
  to reduce their impact on the statistics should be included in the
  explanation. Q3.3 The extent and nature of any uncertainty in the estimates
  should be clearly explained.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q41</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Can you explain the impact of your work/output on downstream
  processes? Are there any risks around these dependencies?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>V1.1 Statistics producers should maintain and refresh their
  understanding of the use and potential use of the statistics and data. They
  should consider the ways in which the statistics might be used and the nature
  of the decisions that are or could be informed by them.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=117 style='height:87.5pt'>
  <td height=117 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:87.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q42</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>All or part of the analysis is reliant on a single person?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>V4 Statistics producers should be creative and motivated to
  improve statistics and data, recognising the potential to harness
  technological advances for the development of all parts of the production and
  dissemination process. T4.3 Sufficient human, financial and technological
  resources should be provided to deliver statistical services that serve the
  public good.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q43</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Is it clear why important decisions were made and who made them?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q2 Producers of statistics and data should use the best
  available methods and recognised standards, and be open about their
  decisions.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=67 style='height:50.0pt'>
  <td height=67 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:50.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q44</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>If changes need to be made to code or datasets, is it
  easy to track who made the changes and when and why they were
  made?<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>V4 Statistics producers should be creative and motivated to
  improve statistics and data, recognising the potential to harness
  technological advances for the development of all parts of the production and
  dissemination process.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q45</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Would another analyst be able to reproduce your analysis output or
  continue the work without talking to you first?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>V5 Statistics and data should be published in forms that enable
  their reuse. Producers should use existing data wherever possible and only
  ask for more where justified.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=133 style='height:100.0pt'>
  <td height=133 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:100.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q46</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Do you use internal peer review to check scripts and code,
  documentation, implementation of methods, processes and outputs?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q3 Producers of statistics and data should explain clearly how
  they assure themselves that statistics and data are accurate, reliable,
  coherent and timely. T4.6 Independent measures, such as internal and external
  audit, peer review and National Statistics Quality Reviews, should be used to
  evaluate the effectiveness of statistical processes. Statistics producers
  should be open about identified areas for improvement.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=133 style='height:100.0pt'>
  <td height=133 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:100.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q47</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Is your code and analysis ever peer reviewed by someone outside
  your team or organisation?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q3 Producers of statistics and data should explain clearly how
  they assure themselves that statistics and data are accurate, reliable,
  coherent and timely. T4.6 Independent measures, such as internal and external
  audit, peer review and National Statistics Quality Reviews, should be used to
  evaluate the effectiveness of statistical processes. Statistics producers
  should be open about identified areas for improvement.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=167 style='height:125.0pt'>
  <td height=167 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:125.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q48</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>What is your assessment of the quality of your analytical
  outputs?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q3 Producers of statistics and data should explain clearly how
  they assure themselves that statistics and data are accurate, reliable,
  coherent and timely. Q3.2 Quality assurance arrangements should be
  proportionate to the nature of the quality issues and the importance of the
  statistics in serving the public good. Statistics producers should be
  transparent about the quality assurance approach taken throughout the
  preparation of the statistics. The risk and impact of quality issues on
  statistics and data should be minimised to an acceptable level for the
  intended uses.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=167 style='height:125.0pt'>
  <td height=167 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:125.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q49</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How do you assure yourself that the analysis you do is
  correct?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q3 Producers of statistics and data should explain clearly how
  they assure themselves that statistics and data are accurate, reliable,
  coherent and timely.Q3.2 Quality assurance arrangements should be
  proportionate to the nature of the quality issues and the importance of the
  statistics in serving the public good. Statistics producers should be
  transparent about the quality assurance approach taken throughout the
  preparation of the statistics. The risk and impact of quality issues on
  statistics and data should be minimised to an acceptable level for the
  intended uses.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q50</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Do the outputs of your analysis align with similar findings from elsewhere? If not, can you explain why?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q3 Producers of statistics and data should explain clearly how
  they assure themselves that statistics and data are accurate, reliable,
  coherent and timely.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=150 style='height:112.5pt'>
  <td height=150 class=xl6519059 width=31 style='height:112.5pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q51</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>If you find outliers or unusual trends in the data, what steps
  do you take to investigate them?</td>
  <td class=xl6519059 width=368 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:276pt'>Q3 Producers of statistics and data should explain clearly how
  they assure themselves that statistics and data are accurate, reliable,
  coherent and timely. Q3.3 The quality of the statistics and data, including
  their accuracy and reliability, coherence and comparability, and timeliness
  and punctuality, should be monitored and reported regularly. Statistics
  should be validated through comparison with other relevant statistics and
  data sources. The extent and nature of any uncertainty in the estimates should
  be clearly explained.</td>
  </tr>
</table>

## Linking the questions to AQuA roles

<style>

  border: 1px solid black;
  border-collapse: collapse;

</style>

<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<TR VALIGN=TOP>
    <th> </th>
    <th> Questions</th>
    <th> Which AQuA role(s) would normally answer this?</th>
    <th> Why are these AQuA roles involved?</th>
</tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>

 <td height=83 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;width:24pt'>Q26</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-left:none;width:241pt'>How will the
  data used in the analysis be processed before and during use?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-left:none;width:137pt'>Analyst,
  analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-left:none;width:225pt'>Analyst
  should collect and manage data. Understand data accuracy and uncertainties.
  Capture, manage and understand implicit assumptions made. Analytical assurer
  should be involved.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=133 style='height:100.0pt'>
  <td height=133 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:100.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q27</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Is the data appropriate given the methods selected?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst, analytical assurer, commissioner</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>Analyst should understand data accuracy and uncertainties and
  capture, manage and understand implicit assumptions made. Analyst should
  engage appropriate subject matter experts, at the appropriate time, when
  collecting data. NB: The commissioner may be a subject matter expert.
  Analytical assurer should also be involved.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q28</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>What are the strengths and limitations of the data you
  use?<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>If applicable, analyst should undertake parametric analysis to
  understand the consequences of missing or uncertain data and assumptions.
  Analytical assurer should be involved.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=117 style='height:87.5pt'>
  <td height=117 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:87.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q29</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Is there a robust relationship between your team and data providers? 
  Do data providers understand how and why you use their data? 
  Do you understand how data providers collect, process and quality assure the data you use?<br>
  </td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>The analytical assurer should expect to review evidence that
  there has been sufficient networking between analysts as the providers of
  data and other evidence sources.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q30</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Is there a formal agreement to set out data content, when
  and how you will get the data? If not, do you think this would be
  helpful?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Commissioner, analyst, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>Commissioner may need to provide the analyst with agreement to
  the use of specific data. Analyst should ensure data formats, units, and
  context are properly understood and handled. Analytical assurer should be
  involved.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=67 style='height:50.0pt'>
  <td height=67 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:50.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q31</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Do you know what quality checks are carried out on the data
  before you receive them?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>Analyst should understand data accuracy and uncertainties and
  capture, manage and understand implicit assumptions made. Analytical assurer
  should also be involved.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=201 style='height:151.0pt'>
  <td height=201 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:151.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q32</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How will you work with your data providers when your data
  requirements change?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Commissioner, analyst, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6930071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>During the design and conduct of analysis phases, the
  commissioner may need to provide the analyst with important information for
  the analysis to proceed or be asked for other essential input, i.e.,
  agreement to the use of specific data and assumptions and provide agreement
  and sign-off to any assumptions that are developed as part of the project.
  Analyst should understand data accuracy and uncertainties and capture, manage
  and understand implicit assumptions made. Analytical assurer should also be
  involved.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=201 style='height:151.0pt'>
  <td height=201 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:151.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q33</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How do you know if your data provider makes a change to their
  systems or processes which could impact the data you receive or the
  analysis you produce?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Commissioner, analyst, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6930071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>During the design and conduct of analysis, the
  commissioner should provide the analyst with the information they need for
  the analysis to proceed. This could include agreement to use datasets,
  setting out of key assumptions and signing off assumptions developed during the project.
  Analyst should understand data accuracy and uncertainties and capture, manage
  and understand implicit assumptions made. The analytical assurer should be
  involved.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=117 style='height:87.5pt'>
  <td height=117 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:87.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q34</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How did you choose the methods for the analysis? How do you know
  the methods you use are appropriate?<span
  style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>During the design phase, the analyst will convert the commission
  into an analytical plan and will consider inputs, analytical
  methodsa and processes, and expected outputs. The analytical
  assurer should check that the proposed design meets the
  commissioner’s requirements.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=67 style='height:50.0pt'>
  <td height=67 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:50.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q35</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Have reasonable alternative methods been explored and
  rejected for good reasons?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst</td>
  <td class=xl6730071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>The analyst should review the analysis as a whole
  and consider carefully whether there are other, better ways in which it could
  be approached.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q36</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How do you know that your analysis is working correctly?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>The analyst should validate that the analysis as set up is 
  what the commissioner requires in order to answer the problem.<span
  style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q37</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Can you describe the assumptions of your analysis, when they
  were made and who made them and signed them off?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>The analyst should capture, manage and understand explicit and implicit
  assumptions made. Analytical assurer should assess whether these are sufficient.<span
  style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q38</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How are assumptions validated and assured before you apply them?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>If applicable, analyst should undertake parametric analysis to
  understand the consequences of missing or uncertain assumptions. Analytical
  assurer should be involved.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=100 style='height:75.0pt'>
  <td height=100 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:75.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q39</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How do you measure and report uncertainty in your analysis?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst, commissioner</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>Analyst should determine and communicate the uncertainty
  associated with the outputs of their analysis so that the commissioner can
  make informed decisions. The range of possible outcomes and their relative
  likelihoods should be described.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=67 style='height:50.0pt'>
  <td height=67 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:50.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q40</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Have you considered the implications of any unquantified
  uncertainties?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst, commissioner</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>If uncertainties are too complex for analysts to quantify,
  even approximately, the analysts should say so in order that the commissioner
  can take this into account.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=67 style='height:50.0pt'>
  <td height=67 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:50.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q41</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Can you explain the impact of your analysis on downstream
  processes? Are there risks around these dependencies?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>Analyst should make sure that the implications of data dependencies or
  relationships to other analysis and methods are understood. Analytical assurer
  should be involved.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q42</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Is all or part of the analysis reliant on a single person?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analytical assurer, analyst, commissioner</td>
  <td class=xl6730071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>Analysis should be peer reviewed at an appropriate and proportionate level by a
  competent person when practicable. Comissioner, analyst and
  analytical assurer should all be involved in each stage of the
  analytical cycle.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q43</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Is it clear why important decisions about the analysis were made, who made them and when?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analytical assurer, analyst</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>The analytical assurer should make sure that a suitable audit trail is
  in place that clarifies the level of validation, scope, and risks associated
  with the analysis. Best practice includes the production of validation log
  books. Analyst should build this audit trail.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=150 style='height:112.5pt'>
  <td height=150 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:112.5pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q44</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>If changes need to be made to code or datasets, is it
  easy to track who made the changes and when and why they were
  made?<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analytical assurer, analyst</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>To make analytical audit easy, you should set up a version control
  system for the analysis as a whole and for code, supporting data and assumptions.
  The Analytical assurer should ensure there is a suitable audit trail that clarifies the level of validation, scope, and
  risks associated with the analysis. Best practice includes the production of
  validation log books. Analyst should build this audit trail.<span
  style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q45</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Would another analyst be able to reproduce your analysis output or
  continue the work without talking to you first?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>Good quality analysis is reproducible. Analyst should check
  that the analytical process reflects the principles of RIGOUR
  (Repeatable, Independent, Grounded in reality, Objective,
  Uncertainty-managed, Robust)</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=133 style='height:100.0pt'>
  <td height=133 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:100.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q46</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Do you use internal peer review to check scripts and code,
  documentation, implementation of methods, processes and outputs?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst, analyical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>The analyst should provide proportionate documentation that
  explains the verification and validation activities that the analysis is subjected to.
  Analysts must perform appropriate test to check the analysis.
  They should commission other verification and validation as required. Analytical assurer
  should confirm that planned validation and verification are sufficient.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=233 style='height:175.0pt'>
  <td height=233 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:175.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q47</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Is your code and analysis ever peer reviewed by someone outside
  your team or organisation?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>Analysts should work with the commissioner to set out the analysis question
  so that appropriate analysis is done. Some analysis may require external
  specialists, so analysts may have responsibilities as part of
  the procurement process. Analysts, including 3rd parties providing
  analysis, should provide proportionate documentatiob describing the
  verification and validation activities undertaken and associated conclusions.
  The analytical assurer advises the commissioner on
  whether appropriate analytical quality assurance has taken place.<span
  style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=133 style='height:100.0pt'>
  <td height=133 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:100.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q48</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>What is your assessment of the quality of your analytical
  outputs?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Commissioner, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>As part of the delivery phase, the commissioner should ensure
  there is an assessment of the level of analytical quality assurance of
  the analysis, noting where there have been trade-offs between time,
  resources and quality. The analytical assurer advises the
  commissioner on whether appropriate analytical quality assurance has taken
  place.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=200 style='height:150.0pt'>
  <td height=200 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:150.0pt;border-top:
  none;width:24pt'>Q49</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>How do you assure yourself that the analysis you do is
  correct?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Commissioner, analyst, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>The analyst must build in checks and processes to ensure that the analysis is correct.
  During the delivery phase, the commissioner should give feedback to assist in
  the correct interpretation of results and determine if the analysis has addressed the commission.
  The analyst should work with the analytical assurer while doing the analysis so that 
  they can comment on whether the analysis meets the needs of the commission
  to ensure best use of the results</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=67 style='height:50.0pt'>
  <td height=67 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:50.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q50</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Do the outputs of your analysis align with similar findings from elsewhere? If not, can you explain why?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Commissioner, analyst</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>When interpreting the results of a piece of analysis, the
  commissioner provides constructive challenge. They work with the analyst
  to explore whether further analysis is needed.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl6530071 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q51</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>If you find outliers or unusual trends in the data, what steps
  do you take to investigate them?</td>
  <td class=xl6530071 width=182 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:137pt'>Analyst, analytical assurer</td>
  <td class=xl6730071 width=299 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:225pt'>If applicable, analyst should undertake parametric analysis to
  understand the consequences of missing or uncertain data and assumptions. 
  The analysis plan should include treatment of unusual values and outliers.
  Analytical assurer should be involved.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
  </tr>
</table>

:::

 </tr>
 <tr height=33 style='height:25.0pt'>
  <td height=33 class=xl657005 width=31 style='height:25.0pt;border-top:none;

  <td class=xl657005 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Does the technical guide and documentation explain how to run the analysis to obtain valid outputs?</td>
  <td> <p id="content" contenteditable>Enter your answer here...                         </p></td>
  <td> <p id="content" contenteditable> Enter full name</p></td>
  <td> <p id="content" contenteditable> Enter date </p></td>

 </tr>
 <tr height=33 style='height:25.0pt'>
  <td height=33 class=xl657005 width=31 style='height:25.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q59</td>
  <td class=xl657005 width=321 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:241pt'>Have you fully documented the analysis code to comply with good practice?</td>
  <td> <p id="content" contenteditable>Enter your answer here...                         </p></td>

## Why the questions matter

<style>
table, th, td {
  border: 1px solid black;
  border-collapse: collapse;
}
</style>

<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<TR VALIGN=TOP>
    <th> </th>
    <th> Question</th>
    <th> Why do I need to know the answer to this?</th>
</tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>

<td height=183 class=xl665210 width=31 style='height:137.5pt;width:24pt'>Q52</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=319 style='border-left:none;width:240pt'>Can you
  give a clear account of what can and cannot be inferred from the analysis?</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=396 style='border-left:none;width:297pt'>Often the
  aim of final output is to inform decison-making. Output might include predictions, involving lots of underlying
  assumptions. It is critical that you support your users to make appropriate use of outputs and understand what can and cannot be
  inferred. Without this, there is a major risk that users may misinterpret findings, make in appropriate comparisons, 
  use the analysis for unsuitable purposes and arrive at the wrong conclusions. For example, a non-expert user may
  wrongly interpret correlation as causation or use incomplete or disconnected data to make forecasts. </td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=100 style='height:75.0pt'>
  <td height=100 class=xl665210 width=31 style='height:75.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q53</td>
  <td class=xl675210 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Have you assessed the limitations of the data and analysis 
  and set out how they affect the quality and use of the outputs?</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>You should describe why limitations related to data
  and methods exist, why they cannot be overcome using the chosen approach and
  their impact on the quality and interpretation of the output. 
  Analysis is of very little value if limitations aren't properly documented
  and explained.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=33 style='height:25.0pt'>
  <td height=33 class=xl665210 width=31 style='height:25.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q54</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Have you sense checked outputs with user groups and
  stakeholders?</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>You should work with users, experts and other relevant
  stakeholders to verify the credibility of outputs and sense check that they are useful.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=117 style='height:87.5pt'>
  <td height=117 class=xl665210 width=31 style='height:87.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q55</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Is uncertainty about data quality, assumptions and
  methodology clearly communicated to users?</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>Outputs are never 100% accurate. Users need to
  understand how uncertainties related to data, assumptions and methodology
  feed into and through the analysis workflow and what this means for the use
  of the outputs. Results must clearly explain how uncertainty affects the
  findings from the analysis, or we risk misinterpretations and
  conclusions being overly reliant on imprecise results.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=117 style='height:87.5pt'>
  <td height=117 class=xl665210 width=31 style='height:87.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q56</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Are the implications of unquantified uncertainties communicated
  to users?</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>You must support your users so they have a sound understanding of relevant
  uncertainties which are not captured in the analysis. When you can,
  make reasonable judgements about the likely size and
  direction of unquantified uncertainty. Provide a qualitative
  description informing users about why the uncertainty cannot be quantified and 
  their likely impact.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=50 style='height:37.5pt'>
  <td height=50 class=xl665210 width=31 style='height:37.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q57</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Is workflow documentation including technical guides and code repositories publicly available?</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>Transparency about your analysis supports proper scrutiny
  and challenge, promotes public trust and encourages re-use of the resources
  you develop.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=100 style='height:75.0pt'>
  <td height=100 class=xl665210 width=31 style='height:75.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q58</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Does the technical guide and documentation explain how to run the analysis to obtain valid outputs?</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>A good technical guide helps everybody to understand what the
  analysis does and how it works. A well-written technical guide is
  essential for effective maintenance of the analysis over the project cycle. 
  It helps users of the analysis to replicate the findings, get
  answers to methodology questions and build their trust in the output.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=83 style='height:62.5pt'>
  <td height=83 class=xl665210 width=31 style='height:62.5pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q59</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Have you fully documented the analysis code to comply with good practice?</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>The technical guide is complemented by fully documented analysis code.
  Code documentation must comply with good practice so new users
  can understand and execute the code as easily and quickly as possible.</td>
 </tr>
 <tr height=100 style='height:75.0pt'>
  <td height=100 class=xl665210 width=31 style='height:75.0pt;border-top:none;
  width:24pt'>Q60</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=319 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:240pt'>Are users able to feed back on the suitability of outputs?</td>
  <td class=xl665210 width=396 style='border-top:none;border-left:none;
  width:297pt'>External critique makes analysis more robust.
  Users should be able to give feedback to your team to ensure that
  results meet their needs. User feedback and customer reviews inform
  you of issues and changes that you might need to make. They also act as evidence
  that users have been consulted.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></td>

  </tr>
</table>

## The questions and the Code of Practice

<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<TR VALIGN=TOP>
    <th> </th>
    <th> Questions</th>
    <th> Which pillar and principle of Code of Practice matter here?  
    *Trustworthiness (T), Quality (Q), Value (V)</th>
